segments.text: Today is July 30, 1980.
This is Terry Anderson.
We're talking to General Joe Hanover about his military career.
This is our second interview.
15th of February, 1941, you went active duty.
That's right.
Could you tell us about that?
You were assigned to the 54th Coastal Artillery.
Could you tell us about that duty?
Yeah.
I'll precede that just a little bit.
A month or six weeks before February 15, I got this alert letter.
And it said that I was being considered for recall for called active duty.
And that's the question that I have any civilian pursuits that would prevent my being recalled or, or was available for a year's duty.
I had no
civilian pursuits that were considered as exempt from military duty.

So I answered in the affirmative and very shortly thereafter I got a copy of a letter ordering me to active duty at Camp Wallace, Hitchcock, Texas with the 54th Coastal Artillery and had Perences colored.
That sounds very strange today because it was
an all-Negro organization with white officers.
It was just being formed.
It was picked up the name of an old World War I artillery unit, so it was a revived number.
There were a great many cadremen who had had several years of Army duty who were made the non-commissioned officers in the Corps of the
of the organization, enlisted men or raw recruits who had just maybe had their basic or very limited amount of training.
Were they all Texans?
No.
No, they were from everywhere, all over.
We initially set up
The organization had headquarters in the basement of the Galvez Hotel in Galveston, Texas.
Camp Wallace was not completed at that time.
It was out some, oh, 15, 18 miles from Galveston.
But as many people remember, prior to World War II, the Department of the Army went into quite a building program of camps and cantonments for this organization.
buildup of military forces.
So Camp Wallace was under construction.
The headquarters was in the Galvez.
And once we got in and got settled, we started a orientation and somewhat of a program of instruction for officers out at Port Crockett, which was on the south end of Galveston Island.
That was an old established Coastal Artillery emplacement.
We had a few regular Army officers, one or two West Pointers, and of course our commanding officer and several of the officers who had former, I mean who were on active duty at the time.
So we spent the first month or six weeks in study and schooling
learning how to be officers on active duty and this sort of thing.
Why do you think that they picked you to be an officer in a black unit?
Well, I think as it turned out, whatever motivated them to do it or whatever guidelines they used apparently were sound.
Most of the officers were from this part of the country.
From Texas or from the South?
Well, most of them were from Texas.
Most of them were from, I'd say the vast majority were from the South, but most of the vast majority were from Texas.
And a great many of them, in fact about 60%, were recently graduated Aggies or Aggies who had graduated some years before.
I think it was because they knew we understood those people a little better.
We associated with them, and I think it turned out to be a fact.
We had good rapport with them.
We understood them and knew what their limitations and capabilities were, and we used them in those areas.
And as the record of all black units went, I think we had a pretty good one.
Was there any times, do you remember any incidents when there were any, what we'd call today race relation problems?
We had really no problem much until we got up to North Carolina.
We stayed in Fort, in Camp Wallace from, oh, sometime in March to June, and then we were transferred to Camp Davis, North Carolina.

Now, even though that was a southern state, as far as integration, or there was no integration at that time, but as far as the geographical division of the country goes, North Carolina was a southern state.
And there were 10,000 colored troops in Camp Davis.
And the nearest town was Wilmington.
And Wilmington only had about 10,000 people.
and really the only place for recreation was Wilmington, and that posed a problem.

The police of Wilmington had considerable problems with, well they'd have had problems with that many soldiers of any kind, but there were just no facilities for that number of black people in a town of 10,000 people.
So there were a good many problems.
Can you describe some of these problems?
Well they were, you know,
Lots of drunken disorderly and lots of objection on the part of the local citizens from the standpoint of coming into the businesses.
At that time, they didn't want them in the restaurants.
They didn't want them in the motel.
Didn't have them.
And they resented it, being soldiers of the United States, and rightfully so, probably.
So that type of thing.
gave the police a great deal of problems.

We had a standing procedure where the officers on duty would have to go into Wilmington and ride and assist the police in reconnaissance and just general overseeing of the situation and helping with crowd control and this sort of thing.
So there were

problems but not really to the extent that we've had some some so-called riots in the last few years right right right how how many what were your responsibilities and how many men did you have under your command well i was in a company yeah when i went there as a as a company officer there were as i remember some 150 soldiers in the company
My responsibility at that time was communications.

If we went out on the bivouac, we set up the communications, the telephones, the communications to the gun emplacements, communications to battalion headquarters, that sort of thing, and also communication training.
I was also the company supply officer, which handled all the supplies that came in.
Each officer had several duties.

But very shortly thereafter, I was assigned as assistant regimental motor officer, which meant that I was responsible for the maintenance and upkeep, third and fourth echelon maintenance of all vehicles in the whole regiment.
So it was a regimental assignment from then on.
Why did they give that to you?
Did they think, well, you were an engineer, and therefore you might know something about motors?
Oh, probably.
Probably.
And they asked me, you know, if my background would lend itself.

Or, you know, a lot of times before they signed somebody back then, they'd ask you, you know, how you thought you could fit in there, or whether you didn't want to sign anybody that was absolutely opposed, even though
You didn't have the fatal say.
A fellow fits a whole lot better if he's agreeable.
Absolutely.
So I was somewhat maintenance inclined.
So I was happy to get the job.
Do you remember what your thoughts were when you were assigned to Camp Wallace and you realized that you were going to be an officer with a black unit?
Do you remember what you thought?
Thank you, ma'am.
I had lived and worked and been around them all my life.
And I really had no second thoughts about signing with a black outfit.
I always felt like that I had good rapport with them.
I had over the years.
Now there were a lot of
A lot of officers assigned to them were absolutely opposed to it.
They fought it to, you know, and many of them got transferred.
Oh, really?
Yes.

And it's probably better because if they were, if they were, they had their mind made up that they didn't want to serve like that, they would have never made good officers in that outfit because we had to do a great deal of the work of noncommissioned officers.
because the educational level, the level of comprehension of those people was way low.
And we just had to do a lot of work that a non-commissioned officer of more education and more know-how would be able to do.
That's right.
Now, when you were down in Camp Wallace, you said in North Carolina there were some problems.
Were there any problems in Texas?
Well, really, we were just receiving these troops.
Oh, I see.
We never did get our full complement until we got to North Carolina.
By the time we got ready to move to North Carolina, we probably had, I would guess, 2,000 in the organization.
But there were some of the same problems in and around Galveston and Hitchcock and Texas City.
There was Houston that was a short ways away that they could share on weekends.
And Houston could accommodate a great many more people than other smaller places.
And then the concentration of soldiers around that area was not 10,000 on 10,000 population.
So it was a completely different situation.
What about white officers?
and other white outfits.
Were there any problems between a black outfit and white outfits, or did they ever work together at any time?
I mean, did they ever have exercises?
Well, I'm sure they did.
We did not.
We had missions on the seacoast, and we did not work really side by side with any other white organizations.

Now we were always in the same, many times we were in the same camps with them, or forts or whatever, and there was some animosity a lot of times in that respect, but we were not really associated with too many other organizations, black or white.
You went out to California, and was this with the same outfit then?
That's right.
And how were the Californians?
toward the black soldiers?
Oh, there was an entirely different situation than there was in Texas.
They were not really segregated out there.
They could go in establishments that could not go in back here, and it really made some difference.
In what way?
Well, I guess the soldiers themselves felt a little bit more
wanted and a little bit more at home where they were more recognized.
It's just a difference.
Now for 20 years we've had the rise of a black power movement in the society and I was wondering if you sensed any unrest among the blacks that you worked with during the year?
Not really.
It was too early probably.
That's right.
And they had a very commendable sense of duty to country, at least the vast majority of them did.
They were fulfilling a job for the defense of their country.
And I doubt that we had any more that were what you'd call unfaithful than they had in white outfits.
Really?
That's right.
Listen, I found years ago that when a black man learns a skill or he learns something that he can be used and be proud of, he is proud, with exception, of course.
One good example, one of my responsibilities later on was teaching survey crews.
as I indicated, surveying in baselines and whatnot.
For the highway?
No, for the Coast Artillery guns.
I see.
For the measurements and whatnot.
We had to have survey crews, and I'd teach these boys enough surveying to where they could run an instrument or figure a few angles and figure little calculations.
We even did a very intricate thing of what is termed in surveying is
shooting Polaris.
In other words, to orient a position, you set up and orient true north by looking at the North Star.
And of course, it revolves in an elliptical circle.
But you set up at night, and you set your instrument on the North Star, and you calculate these deviations, and then you establish a true north-south line.
And we taught them, and we did this.
And that was the proudest survey crew you ever did see, to know that they had, as they called it, shootin' Polaris.
The point is, when they learned a skill or learned a trade, they were proud of it.
But they were good soldiers.
We had exceptionally good ones.
You mentioned their duty, their feeling of duty.
I've read a number of times the autobiography of Malcolm X and other radical blacks who, during the Second World War, they thought that other blacks
who went into the war were fools because they were fighting against tyranny overseas when there was tyranny or segregation at home.
But you never saw any of that.
You never got any of that while you were in charge, while you were in the Army.
Of course, we didn't take the black boys overseas.
I was only with them in the States.
There were a number of them that went overseas, of course.
But I did not go overseas with them.
But I would say I did not see that at all in this organization.
They were very commendable soldiers.

Now, I have one last question about this topic, and that is I know that you grew up with sharecroppers, but did commanding or being in command of a crew of black soldiers during the war, did that change your thoughts about black Americans in any way?
No.
You know, a strange thing about it, we had them, we had them four years, and about the end of that time, they began to assign a few black officers, black second-tenants.
They were beginning to graduate from OCSs.
And this may sound strange, but I had many of them tell me that they did not want to be commanded by black officers.
They'd much rather had white officers.
Why was that?
I don't know, unless it was a feeling of lack of ability and lack of confidence in their leadership.
I really don't know.
But I know I've had many of them ask me, as these black officers began to be assigned to this unit, would they someday have all black officers?
Of course, I didn't know.
tell them I thought it'd be a long while and each time the comment was well we hope not.
Do you think that was a general feeling or was that you think that that was a feeling for you maybe they respected you as an individual?
No I think I think the other officers had the same feeling now the of course it may have been the ones who were
in the area of knowing their responsibility and feeling that they wanted to do a good job, and they were afraid that the leadership of the blacks would not give them a good job they wanted.
And I'm not sure.
But each and every time that question was asked of me, their response was, well, they had rather have the white officers.
Now, that might not be the case today.
Yeah, what do you think we're doing?
This was a good many years ago.
That's very interesting.
Now, right after the war, of course, in about 1948, President Truman signed the executive order which integrated the armed forces.
What was your feeling about that?
What can I say?
Too bad you can't join us.
Let me put it this way.
I grew up in the South.
I grew up serving, working, and playing, and dealing with blacks all my life.
My feeling was, and I said this many times back there, that the best utilization of the blacks would have been in an integrated condition.
Because of this lack of their feeling of sense of responsibility to others and the fact that their leadership abilities are not

about it or were not as high as as the same number of white people and it's uh it may be partly because they didn't want to assume leadership it may have been partly because they weren't capable the better way to use
I think you use their efficiency a whole lot better if you can mix them together and that way you so-called raise the capability level.
What do you think was the impact of Truman's order on the reserves?
You were in the reserves at that time.
Well, I don't remember specifically, except that, you know, that never bothered me at all.
Well, I mean, did the reserves now start accepting blacks in integrated units?
Oh, yeah.
Did the number of blacks in your unit, for example, start to grow?
Not really, because they were really not interested in getting in the reserve nearly as much as the whites for, I guess, a variety of reasons.
I'm not real sure.

one thing may have been that they were out trying to get started in life and didn't could not get time off for reserves or it may have been that they they may have felt that they would still be discriminated against I'm not real sure of what but the number of blacks was very very low in the reserve even on you retired in 1971 that's right oh no no I'm talking about
Back then, but yes, I know, but did it start to grow?
Oh yes, oh yeah.
By the time I retired, there were many blacks in the reserve.
In fact, when I retired, we had a major at that time, a black major on my staff.
Very fine offshore.
But we had lots of blacks.
We had lots of good blacks.
It may sound fun to say good blacks, but you know, in the terminology we're using, that's not a strange comment.
But I've always had a warm place in my heart for a man that's capable.
I don't really care what color he is.
Right, yeah.
When I worked for the highway department, we've got some blacks that, gosh, you know, as fine a people as we had anywhere.
And we had some of them in this black unit I had.
I had some mechanics when I ran this motor maintenance shop that I'd put with anybody's mechanics anywhere in the world.
I actually believe they'd have jumped off the cliff for me.
I used to get in a bind and get a lot of vehicles that were down or disabled or whatever.
If I asked them to work all night, you know, they would never say a word about it.
Just what I asked them to do, they'd do.
Of course, I was usually out there, you know, usually there with them, but I've always had great admiration for capable people.
I don't care what color they are.
Why were you transferred from Coastal Artillery to the Corps of Engineers in 1944?
Well, Coastal Artillery, Seacoast Artillery, was losing its identity, so to speak, because there was not much danger at that time of any invasion in the United States.
And our mission up to that time had been

seacoast protection in california and they were phasing out artillery outfits and seacoast in particular all of the old permanent emplacements along the coast of fort scott uh fort macarthur down at san diego and the same in the los angeles area those were were being phased out because
I presume intelligence said there would be no invasion of the United States.
So the unit that we were in was transferred back to the east and were converted into combat engineer battalions and whatnot.
And then they did not send any of we officers to be assigned with those units.
All those boys would
were going back for training as combat engineers.
So the officers... Josiah.
These officers were being relieved from the units, and then we were assigned to various organizations within our own branches.
So when that happened,
I thought it was time for me to get back in the Corps of Engineers where I really belonged.
So I made an application to be transferred back to the Corps of Engineers.
I stayed back to the Corps of Engineers and was fortunate in getting that assignment and I went then into engineer units.
Okay, what was your duty then in 1944 and 1945?
After being relieved of this artillery unit, I was assigned to a, to a white engineer group.
Very shortly thereafter, the group commander wanted to send me to Fort Belvoir for retread engineer training, even though I was an engineer officer, I mean an engineer by profession.
He wanted me to go back to Fort Belvoir and take a refresher course in army engineering tactics and procedures and whatnot.
So without really having any duties in the white outfit, I went back to Fort Belvoir for six weeks and then came back to the same unit.
And at that time then,
I was assigned to take a company overseas.
Yes, sir.
And let me tell you a funny thing about that assignment.
Excuse me just a minute.
I want you to cut that off.
I want you to meet my daughter before she leaves.
This peculiar thing about my assignment to this engineer company.
When I was in A&M, one of the what we called TAC officers, one of the officers who was the
regular army who monitored the ROTC program out there, was named Johnson, D.T.
Johnson.
And his trademark was this hook pipe that he smoked.
Everybody knew Colonel Johnson.
And he wore little boots.
Of course, engineers have always worn boots near that, you know, that's a trademark.
But he was most un-military looking, had a
posture that's sort of like a duck when you walk in this crooked pipe when you were a captain.
Everybody knew Colonel Johnson.
So I was summonsed over to this group headquarters to be interviewed to take on this new assignment.
They told me that Colonel Johnson wanted to talk with me.
Didn't dawn on me who Colonel Johnson was.
I walked in this office
And it's Colonel D.T.
Johnson, who I had known as a captain at A&M, hadn't seen him since.
And he was the regimental command, the group commander, calling me in to interview me about taking this company that he was fixing to send to Europe.
He picked me because I was an Aggie.
Really?
That's what he told me.
Did he remember you at all?
No.
He just had too many men under his wing.
That's right.
But he told me that he looked through the files of the available officers.
See, I'd just been assigned to the thing, and I was not in the established command structure.
And he said he felt like he could assign me better than he could pull an officer out who had been assigned and been running a company because I was available and had not been assigned.
But he said, also, I noticed you were from A&M, and I have great respect for A&M officers.
That's what he told me.
Now, he may have been just trying to justify sending me to Europe, you know.
But he told me that he had a company that had a 60-day sailing date.
It was a good company, but it had had a weak company commander.
And that he wanted to sign me that company to go to Europe.
And he was right.
It was a good company, and I could tell that it had had weak leadership.
But the point of my story was, here I run into a fellow that I'd known down at A&M.
Never thought about him being a full colonel.
So I took the company.
So you were given the commandment of the company?
That's right.
I was captain at that time.
And how many men did you have under your command?
It was a separate company.
It wasn't attached to any regiment.
It wasn't attached to...

any higher headquarters we we went over as a casual company which meant that i was you know really i was totally in command without any higher headquarters to look to and you were in charge then of the of the uh one two seven four labor uh so that was later this was not it this was the 519th engineering maintenance oh i see yeah okay that's the unit that i took to europe okay
So we processed and got on the boat and went to Europe.
And it was a good outfit.
What did you think of finally getting to the war?
Here you've been in America now.
You've been in the service for four years, and you hadn't seen any combat for years.
Well, really and truly, I was, you know, I felt like, you know...
